Given the GU is viewing the login screen
When the GU has logged into the system
Then the system displays the initiate case details screen for the Other document type
and displays the "Document Information" fields 
and displays the "Additional Request(s)" fields associated with the agency logged in and Other document type. 

Given the SPV is viewing the login screen
When the SPV has logged into the system
Then the system displays the initiate case details screen for the Other document type
and displays the "Document Information" fields for the document selected
and displays the "Additional Request(s)" fields associated with the agency logged in and Other document type.

Document Information fields are located in validation fields below

Tasks: 
- Link to a UI design wireframe: https://sharedservices.dhs.gov/confluence/display/SM/SAVE+Wireframes

Size: M

fields.customfield_17901:
We have a functioning local (OSX) development environment for each app in SAVE MOD. Pending the finalization of Docker images/containers, the team is proceeding with this arrangement:
npm for React development within save-app/front-end/, with an editor preference for Visual Studio Code.

Generic Ruby on Rails development within save-app/.

IntelliJ / Gradle for Java Spring development in save-spring-api/.

Comments on how to get this development env running have been added to the READMEs.
fields.description: Dev Ops to setup dev env

comments.body:
We have a functioning local (OSX) development environment for each app in SAVE MOD. Pending the finalization of Docker images/containers, the team is proceeding with this arrangement:
npm for React development within save-app/front-end/, with an editor preference for Visual Studio Code.

Generic Ruby on Rails development within save-app/.

IntelliJ / Gradle for Java Spring development in save-spring-api/.

Comments on how to get this development env running have been added to the READMEs.

fields.customfield_13430:
SECTION 4 DESIGN & IMPLEMENTATION (COMPLETE IF CR INCLUDES INFRASTRUCTURE CHANGES)

If the CR involves any infrastructure changes, such as VM, database, migration, or changes to any of the other fields listed in Section 4 for any environment, then Section 4 must be filled out in its entirety. The purpose of Section 4 is to capture the necessary information and requirements needed by the ESDO Infrastructure team and the data center support personnel required to install, connect and configure the infrastructure and services in the Enterprise Data Centers in support of ESDO projects.

fields.customfield_17901:
The approach will be to toggle at the level of the Rails API and also at the react level. 

We will build out a custom console in the React application that will allow Kevin to view and modify toggle state. when a toggle is changed in this UI console, the change in state will be sent in an api call to our API which will update the entry in the redis cache for that toggle. the Front end instances will refresh their toggle state with the shared Elasticache instance on page refresh. One concern the team had was that sharing toggles between our client an server code could couple these applications together. We will have to be intentional about maintaining separations between these components of our app despite the mutual dependency on the toggles by now creating many and retiring them early.

We agreed as a team that generally speaking, we will toggle at a very high level. For example we will toggle the initial MVP at the initiate case link in the navigation bar, and the routes that return to legacy after verfication. Within this blocked off code we will not toggle incremental feature releases, but release the MVP as a whole. 

Another general agreement is that we will not toggle new UI features and API calls that do not expose the ability for users to do bad writes to the database. Other than these major high level toggles, db write potential toggles, and major features that need to be a/b tested, we will not toggle.

Removing toggles after a feature is released in production will occur within the same sprint. 

Because there will be so few toggles and they will be so short lived, it is acceptable that our front and and our API will point to the same list of toggles to cover both unreleased API and unreleased UI code that relates to the same feature.

comments.body:
The approach will be to toggle at the level of the Rails API and also at the react level. 

We will build out a custom console in the React application that will allow Kevin to view and modify toggle state. when a toggle is changed in this UI console, the change in state will be sent in an api call to our API which will update the entry in the redis cache for that toggle. the Front end instances will refresh their toggle state with the shared Elasticache instance on page refresh. One concern the team had was that sharing toggles between our client an server code could couple these applications together. We will have to be intentional about maintaining separations between these components of our app despite the mutual dependency on the toggles by now creating many and retiring them early.

We agreed as a team that generally speaking, we will toggle at a very high level. For example we will toggle the initial MVP at the initiate case link in the navigation bar, and the routes that return to legacy after verfication. Within this blocked off code we will not toggle incremental feature releases, but release the MVP as a whole. 

Another general agreement is that we will not toggle new UI features and API calls that do not expose the ability for users to do bad writes to the database. Other than these major high level toggles, db write potential toggles, and major features that need to be a/b tested, we will not toggle.

Removing toggles after a feature is released in production will occur within the same sprint. 

Because there will be so few toggles and they will be so short lived, it is acceptable that our front and and our API will point to the same list of toggles to cover both unreleased API and unreleased UI code that relates to the same feature.
